message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Chatbots for language learning—Are they really useful? A systematic review of chatbot‐supported language learning
Paper Abstract: Abstract Background The use of chatbots as learning assistants is receiving increasing attention in language learning due to their ability to converse with students using natural language. Previous reviews mainly focused on only one or two narrow aspects of chatbot use in language learning. This review goes beyond merely reporting the specific types of chatbot employed in past empirical studies and examines the usefulness of chatbots in language learning, including first language learning, second language learning, and foreign language learning. Aims The primary purpose of this review is to discover the possible technological, pedagogical, and social affordances enabled by chatbots in language learning. Materials & Methods We conducted a systematic search and identifies 25 empirical studies that examined the use of chatbots in language learning. We used the inductive grounded approach to identify the technological and pedagogical affordances, and the challenges of using chatbots for students’ language learning. We used Garrison's social presence framework to analyze the social affordances of using chatbots in language learning Results Our findings revealed three technological affordances: timeliness, ease of use, and personalization; and five pedagogical uses: as interlocutors, as simulations, for transmission, as helplines, and for recommendations. Chatbots appeared to encourage students’ social presence by affective, open, and coherent communication. Several challenges in using chatbots were identified: technological limitations, the novelty effect, and cognitive load. Discussion and Conclusion A set of rudimentary design principles for chatbots are proposed for meaningfully implementing educational chatbots in language learning, and detailed suggestions for future research are presented.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Natural Language Processing (NLP)

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer, and NLP is a subfield of computer science that is closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

### Key Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include: speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

### History

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.(no content)The concept of large language model (LLM) emerged in late 2010s, and LLM is a language model trained with self-supervised learning on vast amount of text.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

Web search results for query: "Language learning"

Links: [{"title":"Language education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_education"},{"title":"Language learning strategies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_learning_strategies"},{"title":"Mobile-assisted language learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile-assisted_language_learning"},{"title":"Glossary of language education terms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_language_education_terms"},{"title":"Language-learning aptitude - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language-learning_aptitude"},{"title":"Heritage language learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heritage_language_learning"},{"title":"Statistical learning in language acquisition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_learning_in_language_acquisition"},{"title":"List of common misconceptions about language learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_common_misconceptions_about_language_learning"},{"title":"Tandem language learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tandem_language_learning"},{"title":"How to Learn Any Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_to_Learn_Any_Language"}]

I've completed a web search on "Language learning" and found comprehensive information. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Language education refers to the processes and practices of teaching a second or foreign language.(no content)There are four main learning categories for language education: communicative competencies, proficiencies, cross-cultural experiences, and multiple literacies.

## Modern Relevance

Increasing globalization has created a great need for people in the workforce who can communicate in multiple languages.(no content)Common languages are used in areas such as trade, tourism, diplomacy, technology, media, translation, interpretation and science.

## Learning Strategies

Language learning strategies is a term referring to the actions that are consciously deployed by language learners to help them learn or use a language more effectively.(no content)Consistently it has been proven that strategies assist learners to become more proficient.

## Modern Approaches

Mobile-assisted language learning (MALL) is language learning that is assisted or enhanced through the use of a handheld mobile device.(no content)Tandem language learning is an approach to language acquisition that involves reciprocal language exchange between tandem partners. In this method, each learner ideally serves as a native speaker of the language the other person intends to learn.

## Common Misconceptions

It is often assumed that young children learn languages more easily than adolescents and adults. However, the reverse is true; older learners are faster.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Systematic review methodology"

Links: [{"title":"Systematic review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systematic_review"},{"title":"Systematic Reviews (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systematic_Reviews_(journal)"},{"title":"GRADE approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GRADE_approach"},{"title":"Literature review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literature_review"},{"title":"Research synthesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research_synthesis"},{"title":"Review article - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_review"},{"title":"Rapid reviews - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapid_reviews"},{"title":"Expert review (method) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expert_review_(method)"},{"title":"Category:Systematic review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Systematic_review"},{"title":"Talk:Systematic review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Systematic_review"}]

Here's an overview of systematic review methodology based on the search results:

## Definition and Purpose

A systematic review focuses on a specific research question to identify, appraise, select, and synthesize all high-quality research evidence and arguments relevant to that question.

## Key Methodological Steps

The methodology involves several structured stages:

1. **Research Question Development**: Best practices involve defining an answerable question and publishing the protocol of the review before initiating it to reduce the risk of unplanned research duplication.

2. **Search Strategy**: The search strategy should be designed to retrieve literature that matches the protocol's specified inclusion and exclusion criteria, with common information sources including scholarly databases such as MEDLINE, Web of Science, Embase, and PubMed.

3. **Study Selection and Quality Assessment**: The titles and abstracts of identified articles can be checked against predetermined criteria for eligibility and relevance, with each included study assigned an objective assessment of methodological quality, preferably using methods conforming to the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement.

## Relationship to Meta-Analysis

Systematic reviews are closely related to meta-analyses, with the distinction being that a meta-analysis uses statistical methods to produce a single number from pooled data, whereas the strict definition of a systematic review excludes that step.

## Reporting Guidelines

The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement suggests a standardized way to ensure transparent and complete reporting of systematic reviews.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about social presence in online learning:

## Definition and Importance

Social presence is measured by the ability to project physical and emotional presence and experience it from others in interactions. More recently, social presence in online learning has been defined as the feeling of community a learner experiences in an online environment.

## Key Dimensions

Within distance learning, social presence rests upon three dimensions: social context, online communication, and interactivity.

## Impact on Learning Outcomes

Research demonstrates that social presence significantly affects student success. Social presence affects different aspects of a learner's experience, such as their success, satisfaction, and performance. Additionally, without social presence learning interaction suffers, which has negative effects on learning performance.

## Strategies to Increase Social Presence

Scholars place high importance on using engagement tactics in online classrooms geared towards increasing social presence and reducing distance.(no content)Asynchronous and synchronous components combined can enliven online interactions, and synchronous sessions can provide both audio and video connections, allowing an interchange involving sight and sound and all the rich nonverbal communication inherent in tone of voice and facial expressions.

## Tools and Platforms

Social media platforms such as Facebook, Skype or Twitter could enhance the communication and interaction between students and their teachers.

Web search results for query: "Chatbot"

Links: [{"title":"Chatbot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatbot"},{"title":"Category:Chatbots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Chatbots"},{"title":"Gemini (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gemini_(chatbot)"},{"title":"Grok (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grok_(chatbot)"},{"title":"List of chatbots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_chatbots"},{"title":"Tay (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tay_(chatbot)"},{"title":"DeepSeek (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeepSeek_(chatbot)"},{"title":"Kimi (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kimi_(chatbot)"},{"title":"Alice AI (AI model family) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice_AI_(AI_model_family)"}]

## Search Results for "Chatbot"

I found comprehensive information about chatbots. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Overview

A chatbot is a software application or web interface designed to have textual or spoken conversations.(no content)Modern chatbots are typically online and use generative artificial intelligence systems that are capable of maintaining a conversation with a user in natural language and simulating the way a human would behave as a conversational partner.

### Modern Chatbot Technology

Modern chatbots like ChatGPT are often based on large language models called generative pre-trained transformers (GPT). They are based on a deep learning architecture called the transformer, which contains artificial neural networks. They generate text after being trained on a large text corpus.

### Popular Chatbots

Chatbots have increased in popularity as part of the AI boom of the 2020s, and the popularity of ChatGPT, followed by competitors such as Gemini, Claude and later Grok. Some notable examples include:

- Gemini (formerly known as Bard) is a generative artificial intelligence chatbot and virtual assistant developed by Google. It was launched on March 21, 2023 in response to the rise of OpenAI's ChatGPT.
- Grok is a generative artificial intelligence chatbot developed by xAI. It was launched in November 2023 by Elon Musk.
- DeepSeek is a generative artificial intelligence chatbot by the Chinese company DeepSeek. Released on 20 January 2025, DeepSeek-R1 surpassed ChatGPT as the most downloaded freeware app on the iOS App Store in the United States by 27 January.

### Business Applications

A major area where chatbots have long been used is customer service and support, with various sorts of virtual assistants.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed all tasks. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** The paper "Chatbots for language learning—Are they really useful?" is classified as a **survey** because it conducts a systematic review of existing empirical studies rather than proposing novel methods.

**Triples Identified and Added:**

1. **Chatbot** (tool) - Examines how chatbots are used as language learning assistants in educational settings.

2. **Language education** (task) - Language learning is the primary domain of application for the chatbots reviewed in this systematic review.

3. **Natural language processing** (method) - The paper discusses chatbots' ability to converse using natural language, which relies on natural language processing techniques.

4. **Systematic review** (method) - The paper conducts a systematic review methodology to identify and analyze 25 empirical studies on chatbot-supported language learning.

5. **Social presence theory** (concept) - The paper uses Garrison's social presence framework to analyze the social affordances of using chatbots in language learning.

**Validation Result:** ✅ All validation checks passed successfully with all Wikipedia URLs verified.

Sources:
- [Chatbot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatbot)
- [Language education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_education)
- [Natural language processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing)
- [Systematic review](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systematic_review)
- [Social presence theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_presence_theory)
